ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course provided a thorough dive into some notable works of postcolonial and World Literatures, mostly novels but including collections of poetry. Large emphasis on close literary analysis of these works and engagement with themes of postcolonial literature.

I improved my close reading skills and learned how historical and political currents influence/interact with the literature we read. I got the opportunity to engage with many amazing texts that I would not have otherwise sought out.

We acquired a basis for what might constitute "world Anglophone literature" - what do each of those terms individually mean? How should we think about reading English literature in places that traditionally would not have spoken nor read the language? How do the afterlives of colonialism still sit with us today?

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most of the readings themselves were very interesting and our professor was very encouraging with questions. The class is great for a discussion space, even if you don't know much about postcolonial literature. The readings and papers together, with the timeline we were given over Zoom, were a lot. This was definitely my most challenging class this term, but would probably be less challenging if it were in-person due to its early start time, number of readings, and the number of deadlines we had.

I think this course is just incredibly difficult to design. Because its somehow supposed to provide a survey of  the entirety of world English lit in one semester an impossible task. There was so much that we did not read in this course, but thats kind of unavoidable. I think I gained a lot from the texts we did read.

Our class size was particularly small (6 people), so it was a very intimate discussion setting that really facilitated sharing with each other interesting things we noticed, common trends, etc. Professor Mukhopadhyay's feedback was definitely also a huge plus. During seminars, she wouldn't mind stepping in and clarifying things that might have been awkwardly or incompletely phrased by students, and she also put forth a lot of her own views when students disagreed or when she thought that we were only seeing one side of the picture. I definitely improved my thinking and writing as a result.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Spacing out of papers, and perhaps less weight given to these assessments would have been nice since the workload, paired with circumstance, was almost unmanageable at times. Discussion was nice to have and everyone seemed engaged.

We did some breakout rooms, but other than that, it was a pretty straightforward seminar, similar to how it would be in non pandemic times. We did manage to access some interesting artifacts virtually though, so that was cool.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This is such an important subject. Trying to learn how to read liters but only reading European and American lit strikes me as kind of ridiculous and navel gaze-y, especially for Americans like myself.

If you are an English major, then you need to take three foundational courses. This should absolutely be one of them. I'd go as far to say that it's downright irresponsible to major in English and not understand the world of English literature beyond the UK and the United States. This course will open so many avenues of new thinking for you, so please take it!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
